section 36(1) to enter land to obtain information) does not apply in relation to land on which works authorised by this Act are being carried out.

Any dispute under this paragraph must be referred to arbitration if the parties so agree, but must otherwise be determined by the Secretary of State for Transport and the Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport acting jointly.

P1group.Title: Power to disapply provision made by paragraphs 1 and 2

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may by order make any provision specified in sub-paragraph (2) in relation to any work constructed in exercise of the powers under this Act.
The provision referred to in sub-paragraph (1) is—

P3para.Text: provision that paragraph 1(2) does not apply in relation to relevant works;
provision that paragraph 1(3) does not apply in relation to land used for or in connection with the carrying out of relevant works;
provision that paragraph 1(8)(a) and (b) do not apply in relation to relevant works;
provision that paragraph 1(10) and (11) do not apply in relation to operations carried out in exercise of the powers under this Act which are, or are carried out in connection with, relevant works;
provision that paragraph 1(12) does not apply in relation to use of a metal detector for the purposes of or in connection with relevant works;
provision that paragraph 1(13) does not apply in relation to removal of objects discovered by any such use;
provision that paragraph 2(1) does not apply in relation to land used, or intended for use, for or in connection with the carrying out of relevant works;
provision that paragraph 2(3) does not apply in relation to land on which relevant works are being carried out.

P2para.Text: In this paragraph, “relevant works” means works which are—

P3para.Text: carried out in exercise of the powers under this Act for the maintenance or alteration of the work referred to in sub-paragraph (1), and
begun on or after such day as may be specified in an order under that subsection.

P2para.Text: An order under sub-paragraph (1) may make different provision for different purposes.
An order under sub-paragraph (1) must be made by statutory instrument; and a statutory instrument containing such an order must be laid before Parliament after being made.

P1group.Title: Inspection and observation of works etc

P2para.Text: Any person duly authorised in writing by the Commission may at any reasonable time enter land on which (or in or under which) a scheduled monument is situated—

P3para.Text: for the purpose of observing or advising upon the exercise in relation to the land of any of the powers under paragraph 1 of Schedule 2 to this Act, or
for the purpose of inspecting, observing or advising upon the carrying out of any works on the land in exercise of any of the other powers under this Act.

P2para.Text: The right under sub-paragraph (1) is not exercisable at a time when the nominated undertaker reasonably considers that it is not safe to exercise it.
A person exercising the right under sub-paragraph (1) must comply with directions given by the nominated undertaker for the purpose of securing compliance with relevant health and safety provisions.
In this paragraph, “scheduled monument” has the same meaning as in the Ancient Monuments and Archaeological Areas Act 1979.

P1para.Text: In this Schedule, references to “the Commission” are to the Historic Buildings and Monuments Commission for England.

P1group.Title: Notice of removal of remains or monument

P2para.Text: Before removing from the land in question any remains or any monument to the deceased, the nominated undertaker must—

P3para.Text: publish in each of two successive weeks in a newspaper circulating in the area where the land is situated, and
at the same time leave displayed in a conspicuous place on or near the land,

P2para.Text: a notice complying with sub-paragraph (2).
A notice under sub-paragraph (1) must—

P3para.Text: identify the land to which it relates,
set out in general terms the effect of paragraphs 2 to 7 (so far as relevant to remains to which sub-paragraph (1) applies),
state where, and in what form, an application under paragraph 2(1) may be made, and
state how the nominated undertaker proposes to carry out its functions under this Schedule with respect to the disposal of the remains or monument.

P2para.Text: No notice is required under sub-paragraph (1) before the removal of any remains or any monument to the deceased where the Secretary of State notifies the nominated undertaker that the Secretary of State is satisfied—

P3para.Text: that the remains were buried more than 100 years ago, and
that no relative or personal representative of the deceased is likely to object to the remains or monument being removed in accordance with this Schedule.

P2para.Text: No notice is required under sub-paragraph (1) before the removal of any remains or any monument to the deceased if—

P3para.Text: on the passing of this Act a licence under section 25 of the Burial Act 1857 (bodies not to be removed from burial grounds without licence of the Secretary of State) is in force in relation to the remains, and
the holder of the licence is the nominated undertaker or a body corporate which is a member of the same group as the nominated undertaker.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (4)(b), “group” means a body corporate and all other bodies corporate which are its subsidiaries within the meaning given by section 1159 of the Companies Act 2006.
In the case of remains in relation to which paragraph 1(1) applies, the nominated undertaker must issue a licence for the removal of the remains if—

P3para.Text: it receives an application in writing from a relative or personal representative of the deceased, and
the application is received before the end of the 56 days after the day on which notice relating to the remains is first published under paragraph 1(1)(a).

P2para.Text: In the case of remains in relation to which paragraph 1(3) applies, the nominated undertaker must issue a licence for the removal of the remains if—

P3para.Text: it receives an application in writing from a relative or personal representative of the deceased, and
the application is received before the nominated undertaker has removed the remains under paragraph 4(1).

P2para.Text: A licensee under this paragraph may remove the remains to which the licence relates and bury them elsewhere or cremate them.
The nominated undertaker must pay the reasonable costs of removal and reburial or cremation under this paragraph.

P1group.Title: Removal of remains by nominated undertaker

P2para.Text: In the case of remains in relation to which paragraph 1(1) applies, the nominated undertaker may remove the remains after the expiry of the period of 56 days referred to in paragraph 2(1)—

P3para.Text: if no application under paragraph 2(1) has been received, or
in a case where one or more applications under paragraph 2(1) have been received, if in the case of each application—

P4para.Text: a licence has been issued, and
at least 28 days have passed since the issue of the licence without the remains having been removed.

P2para.Text: The nominated undertaker must within two months of the removal of remains under sub-paragraph (1)—

P3para.Text: bury them in a place (whether or not consecrated) which is set apart for the purposes of burial, or
cremate them in a crematorium.

P2para.Text: If—

P3para.Text: an application is made to the nominated undertaker under paragraph 2(1),
the application is refused on the ground that the nominated undertaker is not satisfied that the applicant is a relative or personal representative of the deceased,

within the period of 28 days beginning with the date of the notice of refusal the applicant has applied to the county court for a declaration that he or she is a relative or personal representative of the deceased (see paragraph 11(2)(b)), and
that period of 28 days has elapsed without the court having determined the application made to it,

P2para.Text: the nominated undertaker may remove the remains and any monument to the deceased.
The nominated undertaker must, pending the court’s determination, deal with any remains or monument removed under sub-paragraph (3) in such manner as the Secretary of State may direct.
In the case of remains in relation to which paragraph 1(3) applies, the nominated undertaker may remove the remains—

P3para.Text: if no application under paragraph 2(2) has been received, or
in a case where one or more applications under paragraph 2(2) have been received, if in the case of each application—

P4para.Text: a licence has been issued, and
at least 28 days have passed since the issue of the licence without the remains having been removed.

P2para.Text: The nominated undertaker must after the removal of remains under sub-paragraph (1)—

P3para.Text: within 12 months or such longer period as the Secretary of State may direct in relation to the case—

P4para.Text: bury them in a place (whether or not consecrated) which is set apart for the purposes of burial, or
cremate them in a crematorium, or

P3para.Text: deal with them in such other manner, and subject to such conditions, as the Secretary of State may direct.

P2para.Text: If—

P3para.Text: an application is made to the nominated undertaker under paragraph 2(2),
the application is refused on the ground that the nominated undertaker is not satisfied that the applicant is a relative or personal representative of the deceased,

within the period of 28 days beginning with the date of the notice of refusal the applicant has applied to the county court for a declaration that he or she is a relative or personal representative of the deceased (see paragraph 11(2)(b)), and
that period of 28 days has elapsed without the court having determined the application made to it,

P2para.Text: the nominated undertaker may remove the remains and any monument to the deceased.
The nominated undertaker must, pending the court’s determination, deal with any remains or monument removed under sub-paragraph (3) in such manner the Secretary of State may direct.

In the case of remains in relation to which paragraph 1(4) applies, the nominated undertaker may remove the remains and, if it does so, is to be treated for the purposes of this Act as acting under this paragraph and not under the licence under the Burial Act 1857.
The nominated undertaker must within two months of the removal of remains under sub-paragraph (1)—

P3para.Text: bury them in a place (whether or not consecrated) which is set apart for the purposes of burial, or
cremate them in a crematorium.

P2para.Text: But if the Secretary of State is satisfied that the remains were buried more than 100 years ago, the remains are to be dealt with in accordance with paragraph 4(2) instead of sub-paragraph (2).
Where a licence to remove any remains is issued under paragraph 2(1) or (2), the licensee may remove from the land any monument to the deceased and re-erect it elsewhere or otherwise dispose of it.
The nominated undertaker must pay the reasonable costs of removal and re-erection under sub-paragraph (1).

Where any remains are removed under a licence under paragraph 2(1) or (2), the nominated undertaker may remove from the land any monument to the deceased which is not removed by the licensee within 28 days of the issue of the licence.
Where the nominated undertaker removes any remains under paragraph 3, 4 or 5, it may also remove from the land any monument to the deceased.

Where any remains are removed (by a person other than the nominated undertaker) under a licence under section 25 of the Burial Act 1857, the nominated undertaker may remove from the land any monument to the deceased which is not removed by the licensee.
The nominated undertaker may remove any monument removed under this paragraph to the place, if any, where the remains of the deceased are buried or to some other appropriate place.
The nominated undertaker must break and deface any monument removed under this paragraph which is not dealt with under sub-paragraph (4).

Where any remains in relation to which paragraph 1(1) applies are removed under this Schedule, or remains in relation to which paragraph 1(4) applies are removed under paragraph 5(2), the nominated undertaker must, within two months of the removal, provide the Registrar General with a certificate which—

P3para.Text: identifies the remains, so far as practicable,
states the date on which, and the place from which, the remains were removed, and
states the date and place of reburial or cremation.

P2para.Text: Where any remains in relation to which paragraph 1(3) applies are removed under this Schedule, or remains in relation to which paragraph 1(4) applies are removed under paragraph 5(3), the nominated undertaker must, within 12 months of the removal or such longer period as the Secretary of State may direct in relation to the case, provide the Registrar General with a certificate which—

P3para.Text: identifies the remains, so far as practicable,
states the date on which, and the place from which, the remains were removed,
if at the time the certificate is provided the remains have been reburied or cremated, states the date and place of reburial or cremation, and
if at that time the remains have not been reburied or cremated, states where and by whom they are kept.

P2para.Text: Where any monument is removed under this Schedule, the nominated undertaker must, within two months of the removal—

P3para.Text: deposit with the local authority in whose area the monument was situated prior to the removal a record which—

P4para.Text: identifies the monument,
gives any inscription on it,
states the date on which, and the place from which, it was removed, and
states the place, if any, to which it was moved or how it was disposed of, and

P3para.Text: provide the Registrar General with a copy of the record deposited under paragraph (a).

P2para.Text: The nominated undertaker may require any person who removes remains or a monument under this Schedule to provide it with any information about the remains or monument removed which it needs in order to comply with sub-paragraph (1), (2) or (3).
In sub-paragraph (3)(a), “local authority” means the unitary authority or, in a non-unitary area, the district council.

P1group.Title: Discharge of functions by nominated undertaker

P2para.Text: Where the nominated undertaker removes remains in relation to the removal of which a licence has been granted under paragraph 2(1) or (2), it must carry out in accordance with the reasonable requests of the licensee—

P3para.Text: its functions under paragraph 3 or 4 with respect to disposal of the remains, and
if it removes any monument to the deceased, the functions under paragraph 7 with respect to disposal of the monument.

P2para.Text: In a case where more than one licence is granted under paragraph 2(1) or (2) and the licensees make different reasonable requests for the purposes of sub-paragraph (1), the nominated undertaker must carry out the functions referred to in that sub-paragraph in accordance with directions given by the Secretary of State.
Directions under sub-paragraph (2) may include directions that—

P3para.Text: a licensee may apply to the county court to determine how remains or a monument are to be disposed of, and
how the remains or monument are to be dealt with pending the court’s determination.

P1para.Text: The Secretary of State may give such directions as the Secretary of State thinks fit with respect to the carrying out of any function under this Schedule.

P2para.Text: In this Schedule, references to a relative of the deceased are to a person who—

P3para.Text: is a husband, wife, civil partner, parent, grandparent, child or grandchild of the deceased, or
is, or is a child of, a brother, sister, uncle or aunt of the deceased.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of this Schedule, a person is to be taken to be a relative or personal representative of the deceased if—

P3para.Text: the nominated undertaker is satisfied that the person is a relative or personal representative of the deceased, or
the county court, on the application of the person, has declared that the person is a relative or personal representative of the deceased.

P1para.Text: The restriction imposed by section 24(1) of WRA 1991 (restriction on the abstraction of water) does not apply in relation to the abstraction of water for the purposes of or in connection with the construction of the works authorised by this Act.
Section 25 of WRA 1991 (restrictions on impounding) does not apply to anything done in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act with respect to works.

P2para.Text: Section 48A(1) of WRA 1991 (duty not to cause loss or damage to another by the abstraction of water) does not apply in relation to the abstraction of water in connection with the exercise of the powers conferred by this Act.
Where—

P3para.Text: the nominated undertaker causes loss or damage to another person by the abstraction of water in connection with the exercise of the powers conferred by this Act, and
the circumstances are such that causing the loss or damage would have constituted breach of the duty under section 48A(1) of WRA 1991, but for sub-paragraph (1),

P2para.Text: the nominated undertaker must compensate the other person for the loss or damage.
Compensation under sub-paragraph (2) is to be assessed on the same basis as damages for breach of the duty under section 48A(1) of WRA 1991.
Section 48A(5) of WRA 1991 (prohibition of claims in respect of loss or damage caused by abstraction of water which are not claims under that section) has no application to claims under—

P3para.Text: this paragraph, or
Part 5 of Schedule 31.

P1group.Title: Structures in, over or under a main river

P1para.Text: Section 109 of WRA 1991 (consent required for erection, alteration or repair of structures in, over or under a main river) does not apply to anything done in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act with respect to works.

Paragraph 5 of Schedule 1 to FWMA 2010 (consent required for alteration, removal or replacement of designated feature) does not apply to anything done in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act with respect to works.

Paragraph 7 of Schedule 3 to FWMA 2010 (approval required for drainage system for construction work) does not apply in relation to anything done in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act with respect to works.

P1group.Title: Communication with public sewers in London

P1para.Text: Section 106(8) of the Water Industry Act 1991 (which qualifies the general right to communicate with the public sewers of a sewerage undertaker in Greater London) does not apply where the proposed communication involves a drain or sewer serving Phase One of High Speed 2.
Part 4 of the Eels (England and Wales) Regulations (S.I. 2009/3344) (passage of eels) does not apply to anything done in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act with respect to works.
In this Schedule—

Para.Text: “abstraction” has the same meaning as in WRA 1991;
“FWMA 2010” means the Flood and Water Management Act 2010;
“WRA 1991” means the Water Resources Act 1991.

P2para.Text: Nothing in—

P3para.Text: Part 1 of the 1984 Act with respect to building regulations, or
any building regulations,

P2para.Text: applies to a building held by the Secretary of State or the nominated undertaker and used, or intended for use, by the nominated undertaker for the purposes of its undertaking under this Act.
Sub-paragraph (1) does not apply in relation to a building which is a house or hotel.
Sub-paragraph (1) does not apply in relation to a building which is used as offices or showrooms unless it forms part of a railway station or other railway facility.
The reference in sub-paragraph (3) to a “railway facility” includes a maintenance depot, electrical supply facility or stabling facility used for the purposes of a railway.

The reference in sub-paragraph (1)(b) to building regulations does not include the provisions listed in regulation 34(1) of the Building Regulations 2010 (S.I. 2010/2214) (requirements relating to energy efficiency).

P1para.Text: In section 61 of the 1984 Act—

P3para.Text: subsection (2) (local authority officers to have access to drain repair works), and
subsection (3) (offence for failure to comply with section 61),

P1para.Text: do not apply to the repair, reconstruction or alteration of an underground drain which is carried out for Phase One purposes.

Where works described in section 62(1)(a), (b) or (c) of the 1984 Act (reconstruction and other drain works) are carried out for Phase One purposes, section 62 of the 1984 Act (which requires drains to be disconnected when they become disused or unnecessary in consequence of reconstruction and other works) has effect as if—

P3para.Text: in subsection (1), for “as the local authority may reasonably require” there were substituted “as the person considers necessary”,
subsections (2) and (3) were omitted,
for subsection (4) there were substituted—

P2para.Text: Before carrying out works described in subsection (1)(a), (b) or (c), the person carrying out the works must give at least 48 hours’ notice to the local authority.

P3para.Text: subsection (5) were omitted.

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where—

P3para.Text: the nominated undertaker is given a notice under section 73(1) of the 1984 Act (notice requiring chimney of adjoining building to be raised and requiring owner or occupier of that building to allow access to it for that purpose),

the taller building is a building held, or to be held, by the Secretary of State or the nominated undertaker and used, or intended for use, by the nominated undertaker for the purposes of its undertaking under this Act, and
the owner or occupier of the adjoining building referred to in section 73(1)(b) of the 1984 Act serves a counter-notice on the nominated undertaker.

P2para.Text: The owner or occupier of the adjoining building may not enter upon relevant Phase One land, for the purposes of carrying out the work to which the counter-notice relates, without the consent of the Secretary of State or the nominated undertaker.

“Relevant Phase One land” means land held by the Secretary of State or the nominated undertaker and used, or intended for use, by the nominated undertaker for the purposes of its undertaking under the Act.

Where, by reason of the withholding of consent for the purposes of sub-paragraph (2), the owner or occupier of the adjoining building is unable to carry out the work to which the counter-notice relates, the counter-notice ceases to have effect.
In this paragraph, references to “the taller building” and a “counter-notice” are to be construed in accordance with section 73 of the 1984 Act.

P1group.Title: Construction of cellars and rooms below subsoil water level

P2para.Text: Section 74(1) of the 1984 Act (which requires local authority consent for the construction of a cellar or room below subsoil water level in, or as part of, a house, shop, inn, hotel or office) does not apply to the construction of a cellar or room in connection with a shop, inn, hotel or office which forms part of a railway station or other railway facility which is being used, or which is intended for use, by the nominated undertaker for the purposes of its undertaking under this Act.
The reference in sub-paragraph (1) to a “railway facility” includes a maintenance depot, electrical supply facility or stabling facility used for the purposes of a railway.

P1para.Text: In this Schedule—

Para.Text: “the 1984 Act” means the Building Act 1984;
“building regulations” has the same meaning as in the 1984 Act (see section 122 of that Act).

P1para.Text: In this Schedule, “the 1996 Act” means the Party Wall etc Act 1996.
No notice under section 1(2) or (5) of the 1996 Act (notice before building on line of junction with adjoining land) is required before the building of any wall for Phase One purposes.
Sections 1(6) and 2 of the 1996 Act (rights of adjoining owners) do not have effect to confer rights in relation to—

P3para.Text: anything held by the Secretary of State or the nominated undertaker and used, or intended for use, by the nominated undertaker for the purposes of its undertaking under this Act, or
land on which there is any such thing.

P1para.Text: No party structure notice under section 3 of the 1996 Act is required before the exercise of any right conferred by section 2 of that Act (right to repair etc party wall) for the purposes of or in connection with—

P3para.Text: the construction of the works authorised by this Act, or
the maintenance of any such work during the period beginning with the date on which the work is completed and ending 5 years after the date on which it is brought into general use.

P1para.Text: Section 6 of the 1996 Act (underpinning of adjoining buildings) does not apply in relation to a proposal to excavate, or excavate for and erect anything, for Phase One purposes.

P2para.Text: Where—

P3para.Text: a building owner (within the meaning of the 1996 Act) serves a notice under section 6(5) of that Act, and
the building or structure of the adjoining owner (within the meaning of that Act) referred to in that provision is a building or structure—

P4para.Text: erected for Phase One purposes, or
situated on land held by the Secretary of State or the nominated undertaker for the purposes of the nominated undertaker’s undertaking under this Act,

P2para.Text: section 6 of that Act has effect as if it were subject to the following modifications.
Those modifications are—

P3para.Text: that subsection (3) is omitted, and
the substitution for subsections (6) and (7) of—

P2para.Text: The notice referred to in subsection (5) (“the proposals notice”)—

P3para.Text: shall be accompanied by plans and sections showing—

P4para.Text: the site and depth of any excavation the building owner proposes to make;
if he proposes to erect a building or structure, its site; and

P3para.Text: where the notice includes a proposal to underpin or otherwise strengthen or safeguard the foundations of
the building or structure of the adjoining owner, shall—

P4para.Text: include a detailed description of those works; and
specify the building owner’s programme for carrying them out.

P2para.Text: The adjoining owner may serve a notice on the building owner consenting to the proposals notice.
Where the proposals include the carrying out of works mentioned in subsection (6)(b), the consent notice served under subsection (6A) must state whether the adjoining owner—

P3para.Text: is to carry out those works himself, or
requires the works to be carried out by the building owner.

P2para.Text: If an owner on whom a proposals notice has been served does not serve a consent notice within the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the proposals notice was served, he shall be deemed to have dissented from the notice and a dispute shall be deemed to have arisen between the parties.

Works to underpin or otherwise strengthen or safeguard the foundations of the building or structure of the adjoining owner (whether proposed in the proposals notice or otherwise) are to be carried out by the adjoining owner, unless the building owner is required to carry them out—

P3para.Text: by virtue of a requirement within subsection (6B)(b), or
where a dispute is deemed to have arisen between the parties in relation to any matter, by a notice served by the adjoining owner on the building owner within the period of 14 days beginning with—

P4para.Text: the day on which the parties settle the dispute, or
the day on which an award is made under section 10 in relation to the dispute.

P2para.Text: The works (whether carried out by the adjoining owner or the building owner) are to be carried out—

P3para.Text: at the building owner’s expense, and

in accordance with the description and programme agreed by the parties (whether by virtue of a consent notice or in connection with the settlement of any dispute) or determined in accordance with section 10 (in the case of a dispute in relation to which an award is made under that section).

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where a dispute arises or is deemed to have arisen in respect of a matter connected with any work to which the 1996 Act relates and the work—

P3para.Text: is required for Phase One purposes, or
relates to a building or structure situated on land held by the Secretary of State or the nominated undertaker for the purposes of the nominated undertaker’s undertaking under this Act.

P2para.Text: In such a case, the 1996 Act has effect as if for section 10 (resolution of disputes) there were substituted—

Where a dispute arises or is deemed to have arisen between a building owner and an adjoining owner in respect of any matter connected with any work to which this Act applies, the dispute is to be settled by a single arbitrator, to be—

P3para.Text: agreed on by both parties, or
in default of agreement, appointed on the application of either party, after notice in writing to the other, by the President of the Institution of Civil Engineers.
agreed on by both parties, or
in default of agreement, appointed on the application of either party, after notice in writing to the other, by the President of the Institution of Civil Engineers.

P2para.Text: If the arbitrator—

P3para.Text: refuses to act;
neglects to act for a period of ten days beginning with the day on which either party serves a request on the arbitrator;
dies before the dispute is settled; or
becomes or deems himself or herself incapable of acting,

P2para.Text: subsection (1) applies again.
The arbitrator must settle by award any matter—

P3para.Text: which is connected with any work to which this Act relates, and
which is in dispute between the building owner and the adjoining owner.

P2para.Text: An award may determine—

P3para.Text: the right to execute any work;
the time and manner of executing any work; and
any other matter arising out of or incidental to the dispute including the costs of making the award.

P2para.Text: But, unless otherwise agreed between the building owner and the adjoining owner, any period appointed by the award for executing any work does not begin to run until after the end of the period prescribed by this Act for service of the notice in respect of which the dispute arises or is deemed to have arisen.
The reasonable costs incurred in—

P3para.Text: making or obtaining an award under this section,
reasonable inspections of work to which the award relates, and
any other matter arising out of the dispute,

P2para.Text: are to be paid by such of the parties as the arbitrator determines.
Where the arbitrator makes an award, the arbitrator must serve it forthwith on the parties.
The award is conclusive and must not except as provided by this section be questioned in any court.
Either of the parties to the dispute may appeal to the county court against the award within the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the award is served on the party making the appeal.
On such an appeal, the county court may—

P3para.Text: rescind the award or modify it in such manner as the court thinks fit; and
make such order as to costs as the court thinks fit.

P2para.Text: Where the 1996 Act has effect as mentioned in sub-paragraph (2)—

P3para.Text: section 7(5) has effect as if the words “(or surveyors acting on their behalf)” were omitted,
section 8(5) has effect as if the reference to a surveyor appointed or selected under section 10 were to an arbitrator agreed or appointed under section 10 (as modified by sub-paragraph (2)),
section 8(6) has effect as if it provided for the arbitrator to give notice of its intention to enter land or premises, and
section 12(3)(b) has effect as if the reference to the surveyor or surveyors were to the arbitrator.

P2para.Text: Where, by virtue of paragraph 6, work to which a notice under section 6(5) of the 1996 Act relates are carried out by an adjoining owner, sections 13 and 14 of that Act have effect subject to the following modifications.

Section 13(1) has effect as if it enabled the adjoining owner, within the period of two months beginning with the day of the completion of the work, to serve on the building owner an account in writing showing particulars and expenses of the work.
Section 13(2) has effect as if it enabled the building owner to serve on the adjoining owner a notice objecting to the account served under section 13(1) (as modified by sub-paragraph (2)).
Section 14 has effect as if—

P3para.Text: for subsection (1) there were substituted—

P2para.Text: All expenses to be defrayed by a building owner in accordance with an account served under section 13 shall be paid by the building owner.

P3para.Text: subsection (2) were omitted.

P2para.Text: The following enactments (which control obstructions of the highway in connection with works relating to buildings) do not apply to anything erected, placed or retained in, upon or over a highway for the purposes of or in connection with the exercise of the powers conferred by this Act—

P3para.Text: section 15(1) of the Greater London Council (General Powers) Act 1970 (c. lxxvi), and
section 169(1) of the Highways Act 1980.

P2para.Text: Section 141 of the Highways Act 1980 (c. 66) (restriction on planting trees or shrubs in or near carriageway) does not apply to any tree or shrub planted for the purposes of or in connection with the exercise of the powers conferred by this Act.

Section 167 of the Highways Act 1980 (powers relating to retaining walls near streets) does not apply to any length of a retaining wall erected on land held by the Secretary of State or nominated undertaker and used, or intended for use, by the nominated undertaker for the purposes of its undertaking under this Act.

Nothing in section 8(2) to (5) of the Greater London Council (General Powers) Act 1986 (c. iv) (power of borough councils in relation to retaining walls supporting the carriageway or footway of certain highways) applies with respect to any retaining wall erected in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act.

The provisions of this paragraph apply in relation to a highway for which the Secretary of State is the highway authority only if the Secretary of State consents (and consent may be subject to conditions).

The powers conferred by section 56(1) and (1A) of the New Roads and Street Works Act 1991 (powers to give directions as to the timing of proposed and subsisting street works) do not apply in relation to works proposed to be, or being, carried out under the powers conferred by this Act.
Section 56A of that Act (power to give directions as to placing of apparatus) does not apply in relation to the placing of apparatus in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act.

No restriction under section 58(1) of that Act (power to impose restriction on execution of street works following completion of substantial road works) has effect in relation to works carried out under the powers conferred by this Act.

Section 61(1) of that Act (under which the consent of the street authority is required for the placing of apparatus in a protected street) does not apply to the placing of apparatus in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act.

Section 62(2) of that Act (power following designation of protected street to require removal or repositioning of apparatus already placed in the street) does not apply in relation to apparatus placed in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act.

Section 62(4) of that Act (power when designation as protected street commences or ceases to give directions with respect to works in progress) does not apply in relation to works being carried out under the powers conferred by this Act.

Section 63(1) of that Act (under which Schedule 4 to that Act has effect for requiring the settlement of a plan and section of street works to be executed in a street designated by the street authority as having special engineering difficulties) does not apply in relation to works to be executed under the powers conferred by this Act.

The power conferred by section 73A(1) of that Act (power to require undertaker to re-surface street) may not be exercised in relation to an undertaker who is within subsection (2) of that section because of—

P3para.Text: having given a notice in respect of works proposed to be carried out under the powers conferred by this Act, or
executing, or having executed, works under those powers.

P2para.Text: Nothing in section 74A of that Act (power to make regulations requiring payment of charges for street works), or in regulations made under it, applies in relation to the execution of works under the powers conferred by this Act.

No contribution is payable under section 78A(1)(b) of that Act (contributions by other undertakers to costs incurred in executing works specified in a re-surfacing notice) because of the execution of works under the powers conferred by this Act.

Schedule 3A to that Act (restriction on works following substantial street works) does not apply where a notice under section 54 (advance notice of certain works) or 55 (notice of starting date of works) of that Act is in respect of works to be executed under the powers conferred by this Act.

No notice under paragraph 2(1)(d) of that Schedule (power by notice to require notification of works which an undertaker proposes to carry out in a part of a highway to which a proposed restriction applies) has effect to require the notification of works proposed to be carried out under the powers conferred by this Act.
No directions under paragraph 3 of that Schedule (directions as to the date on which undertakers may begin to execute proposed works) may be issued to the nominated undertaker.

Paragraph 3(4) of that Schedule (under which it is an offence for an undertaker to execute street works before the completion of certain other street works) does not apply in relation to the execution of works under the powers conferred by this Act.
Paragraph 5(1) of that Schedule (effect of direction under paragraph 4 restricting further works) does not apply in relation to the execution of works under the powers conferred by this Act.

The provisions of this paragraph apply in relation to a street for which the Secretary of State is the street authority only if the Secretary of State consents (and consent may be subject to conditions).

Nothing in Part 3 of the Traffic Management Act 2004 (permit schemes), or in any permit scheme or permit regulations under that Part, applies in relation to the carrying out of works under the powers conferred by this Act.
This paragraph applies in relation to—

P3para.Text: a permit scheme under Part 3 of the 2004 Act in respect of a street for which the Secretary of State is the highway authority, or
a permit scheme prepared by the Secretary of State under section 33(4) of the 2004 Act,

P2para.Text: only if the Secretary of State consents (and consent may be subject to conditions).
In this Schedule “lorry ban order” means—

P3para.Text: the Greater London (Restriction of Goods Vehicles) Traffic Order 1985, or
any other order made at any time under section 1 or 6 of the Road Traffic Regulation Act 1984 which to any extent imposes—

P4para.Text: a prohibition or restriction on the use of heavy commercial vehicles, or any class of such vehicles, in an area, zone or place, or on a road, specified in the order, or
a requirement that heavy commercial vehicles, or any class of such vehicles, use a specified through route.

P2para.Text: The reference in sub-paragraph (1)(b)(i) to a prohibition or restriction on the use of heavy commercial vehicles on a road does not include a prohibition or restriction on their use on part of the width of a road.
It is immaterial for the purposes of sub-paragraph (1)(b) whether the prohibition, restriction or requirement is subject to exceptions.
This paragraph applies in relation to a lorry ban order made by the Secretary of State only if the Secretary of State consents (and consent may be subject to conditions).

P1group.Title: Required provision in lorry ban orders

P2para.Text: If a lorry ban order referred to in paragraph 1(1)(b) does not contain the required provision, it is to be treated as if it did.
The required provision is provision to the effect that—

P3para.Text: a person proposing to use heavy commercial vehicles in connection with authorised works in a way which would otherwise constitute a breach of the prohibition, restriction or requirement referred to in paragraph 1(1)(b) may apply for the issue of a permit in respect of that use, and
the use authorised by such a permit does not constitute a breach of the prohibition, restriction or requirement.

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where a person proposes to undertake a journey before the end of the next complete eight working days, being a journey—

P3para.Text: proposed to be undertaken in connection with the carrying out of authorised works, and
for which a permit under a lorry ban order is required if the prohibition, restriction or requirement is not to be breached.

P2para.Text: The person may apply for a permit under the lorry ban order for the journey by giving the details mentioned in sub-paragraph (3) by telephone or by electronic means to the authority responsible for dealing with permits under the order.
The details referred to above are—

P3para.Text: the identity of the applicant,
how the applicant may be contacted by telephone or by electronic means,
the registration number of the vehicle to which the application relates,
the authorised works in connection with which the journey is to be undertaken,
whether any approved arrangements are relevant to the application and, if so, what they are,
the date when the journey is proposed to be undertaken, and

in the case of an order made otherwise than by the Secretary of State, whether it is proposed to stop in the relevant area for delivery or collection purposes and, if so, the place or places and time or times at which it is proposed to do so, and

in the case of an order made by the Secretary of State, such details of the place or places and time or times at which it is proposed to stop for delivery or collection purposes as may be set out in conditions attaching to consent given under paragraph 1(5).

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (3)(g) “relevant area” means—

P3para.Text: Greater London, if the area, zone, place or road specified in the order is in Greater London, and
the area of the traffic authority, in any other case.

P2para.Text: An authority responsible for dealing with permits under a lorry ban order must make arrangements enabling applications under paragraph 3 to be made at any time.

Once an application for a permit has been made under paragraph 3, then, for the purpose of any relevant journey, the application is to be treated as granted subject to such conditions as the Secretary of State may by order specify.

A journey is a relevant journey for the purposes of sub-paragraph (2) if it is begun before the authority to which the application is made has communicated its decision on the application to the applicant by the means specified by the application under paragraph 3(3)(b).
The power to make an order under sub-paragraph (2) includes—

P3para.Text: power to make different provision for different cases, and
power to make an order varying or revoking any order previously made under that provision.

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where an application for the issue of a permit under a lorry ban order—

P3para.Text: is made under paragraph 3, or
is otherwise expressed to be made in connection with the carrying out of authorised works.

P2para.Text: The application must be granted if the issue of a permit is reasonably required—

P3para.Text: for the purpose of enabling authorised works to be carried out in a timely and efficient manner, or
for the purpose of enabling authorised works to be carried out in accordance with approved arrangements.

P2para.Text: If the application is granted, no condition may be imposed which is likely to obstruct the carrying out of authorised works—

P3para.Text: in a timely and efficient manner, or
in accordance with approved arrangements.

P2para.Text: An applicant aggrieved by a decision under sub-paragraph (2) or (3) may appeal to the Secretary of State by giving notice of the appeal to—

P3para.Text: the Secretary of State, and
the authority whose decision is appealed against,

P2para.Text: within 28 days of notification of the decision.
On an appeal under sub-paragraph (4), the Secretary of State may allow or dismiss the appeal or vary the decision of the authority whose decision is appealed against.

If, on an appeal under sub-paragraph (4) against a decision under sub-paragraph (3), the Secretary of State varies the decision, the variation has effect from and including the date on which the appeal was constituted or such later date as the Secretary of State may specify.
The applicant may not challenge a decision under sub-paragraph (3) otherwise than by an appeal under sub-paragraph (4).
In this Schedule—

Para.Text: “approved arrangements” means arrangements approved for the purposes of paragraph 6 of Schedule 16;
“authorised works” means works authorised by this Act;
“electronic means” includes e-mail and the internet;
“heavy commercial vehicle” has the same meaning as in the Road Traffic Regulation Act 1984 (see section 138 of that Act);
“traffic authority” has the same meaning as in the Road Traffic Regulation Act 1984 (see section 121A of that Act);
“working day” means any day which is not a Saturday or Sunday, Christmas Day, Good Friday or a bank holiday in England and Wales under the Banking and Financial Dealings Act 1971.

P2para.Text: In this Schedule references to the issuing of a permit include the giving of any consent.

P1group.Title: Control of noise on construction sites

P2para.Text: In the Control of Pollution Act 1974, sections 60 (control of noise on construction sites) and 61 (prior consent for work on construction sites) each have effect, in relation to works carried out in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act, as if—

P3para.Text: in subsection (7) (appeal against notice or against failure to give consent or the giving of qualified consent), for “a magistrates’ court” there were substituted “the Secretary of State”, and
after that subsection there were inserted—

P2para.Text: If within seven days of the giving of notice of appeal under subsection (7) of this section the appellant and the local authority so agree, the appeal shall, instead of being determined by the Secretary of State, be referred to arbitration.

The Secretary of State for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs and the Secretary of State for Transport acting jointly may, in relation to appeals which (by virtue of sub-paragraph (1)) are referred to arbitration under section 60(7A) or 61(7A) of the Control of Pollution Act 1974, by regulations make any such provision as may be made by regulations under section 70 of that Act in relation to appeals under Part 3 of that Act to the Secretary of State.

Regulations under sub-paragraph (2) must be made by statutory instrument; and a statutory instrument containing such regulations is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.

P1group.Title: Defences to proceedings relating to statutory nuisance

P1para.Text: In proceedings for an offence under section 80(4) of the Environmental Protection Act 1990 (offence of contravening abatement notice) in respect of a statutory nuisance falling within section 79(1)(g) or (ga) of that Act where the offence consists in contravening requirements imposed by virtue of section 80(1)(a) or (b) of that Act, it is a defence to show that the nuisance—

P3para.Text: is a consequence of—

P4para.Text: the construction or maintenance of the works authorised by this Act, or
the operation of Phase One of High Speed 2, and

P3para.Text: cannot reasonably be avoided.

P2para.Text: Where proceedings are brought under section 82(1) of the Environmental Protection Act 1990 (summary proceedings by person aggrieved by statutory nuisance) in relation to—

P3para.Text: a statutory nuisance falling within section 79(1)(g) of that Act (noise emitted from premises), or
a statutory nuisance falling within section 79(1)(ga) of that Act (noise emitted by vehicle, machinery or equipment in a street),

P2para.Text: no order may be made, and no fine may be imposed, under section 82(2) of that Act if the defendant shows that sub-paragraph (2) or (3) applies.
This sub-paragraph applies if the nuisance—

P3para.Text: relates to premises or, as the case may be, to a vehicle, machinery or equipment, used by the nominated undertaker for the purposes of or in connection with the exercise of the powers conferred by this Act with respect to works, and

is attributable to the carrying out of works which are being carried out in accordance with a notice served under section 60, or a consent given under section 61 or 65, of the Control of Pollution Act 1974.

P2para.Text: This sub-paragraph applies if the nuisance—

P3para.Text: is a consequence of—

P4para.Text: the construction or maintenance of the works authorised by this Act, or
the operation of Phase One of High Speed 2, and

P3para.Text: cannot reasonably be avoided.

P1para.Text: The following provisions of the Control of Pollution Act 1974—

P3para.Text: section 61(9) (consent for work on construction site to include statement that it does not of itself constitute a defence to proceedings under section 82 of the Environmental Protection Act 1990), and
section 65(8) (corresponding provision in relation to consent for registered noise level to be exceeded),

P1para.Text: do not apply where the consent relates to the use of premises or, as the case may be, of a vehicle, machinery or equipment by the nominated undertaker for the purposes of or in connection with the exercise of the powers conferred by this Act with respect to works.

P2para.Text: Nothing in section 3 of the London Squares Preservation Act 1931 (protection of squares) has effect in relation to anything done for the purposes of or in connection with the exercise of the powers conferred by this Act with respect to works.

Nothing in any agreement under section 9 of that Act (agreements between local authority and owner of a protected square) has effect to prohibit, restrict or impose any condition on the exercise of the powers conferred by this Act with respect to works.

P1para.Text: Nothing in the London Overground Wires &c. Act 1933, or in any byelaw made under that Act, extends or applies to any wires or part of a wire erected or placed, proposed to be erected or placed, or for the time being maintained, by the nominated undertaker in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act.

P2para.Text: The following provisions of the London Building Acts (Amendment) Act 1939 do not apply to anything held by the Secretary of State or the nominated undertaker and used, or intended for use, by the nominated undertaker for the purposes of its undertaking under this Act—

P3para.Text: Part 3 (construction of buildings and structures generally),
Part 4 (construction of special and temporary buildings and structures), and
Part 5 (means of escape in case of fire).

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraph (1) does not apply in relation to a building which is a house or a hotel.
Sub-paragraph (1) does not apply in relation to a building which is used as offices or showrooms unless it forms part of a railway station or other railway facility.
The reference in sub-paragraph (3) to a “railway facility” includes a maintenance depot, electrical supply facility or stabling facility used for the purposes of a railway.

P1group.Title: West Midlands County Council Act 1980 (c. xi)

P2para.Text: Section 11 of the West Midlands County Council Act 1980 (floodlighting) does not apply to floodlighting provided for the purposes of or in connection with the exercise of the powers conferred by this Act with respect to works.
Section 15 of that Act (dust) does not apply to building operations carried out in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act.

Section 16 of that Act (noise from air-powered tools and compressors) does not apply to equipment used for the purposes of or in connection with the exercise of the powers conferred by this Act with respect to works.

Section 21 of that Act (powers of entry for Prevention of Damage by Pests Act 1949) does not apply in relation to any land held by the nominated undertaker and used, or intended for use, by the nominated undertaker for the purposes of its undertaking under this Act.

Section 46 of that Act (building plans: access for fire brigade) does not apply to plans relating to a building held by the Secretary of State or the nominated undertaker and used, or intended for use, by the nominated undertaker for the purposes of its undertaking under this Act.

Part 7 of that Act (storage of flammable materials) does not apply in relation to a stack on land held by the Secretary of State or the nominated undertaker and used, or intended for use, by the nominated undertaker for the purposes of its undertaking under this Act.

Section 84 of that Act (works erected etc over watercourses) does not apply to a work (as defined in that section) belonging to the Secretary of State or the nominated undertaker and used, or intended for use, by the nominated undertaker for the purposes of its undertaking under this Act.
Section 7 of the Staffordshire Act 1983 (plans for new streets) does not apply to any work carried out in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act.
Section 10(1)(b) of that Act (ornamental or mown land) does not apply to the use of a vehicle which is reasonably necessary—

P3para.Text: for the purposes of, or in connection with, the exercise of the powers conferred by this Act with respect to works, or
for the purposes of the nominated undertaker’s undertaking under this Act.

P2para.Text: Section 12 of that Act (dust) does not apply to building operations carried out in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act.

Section 16 of that Act (powers of entry for Prevention of Damage by Pests Act 1949) does not apply in relation to any land held by the nominated undertaker and used, or intended for use, by the nominated undertaker for the purposes of its undertaking under this Act.

Section 26 of that Act (building plans: access for fire brigade) does not apply to plans relating to a building held by the Secretary of State or the nominated undertaker and used, or intended for use, by the nominated undertaker for the purposes of its undertaking under this Act.

Part 7 of that Act (storage of flammable materials) does not apply in relation to a stack on land held by the Secretary of State or the nominated undertaker and used, or intended for use, by the nominated undertaker for the purposes of its undertaking under this Act.
Section 5(2)(a) of the Oxfordshire Act 1985 (grass verges and open spaces) does not apply to the use of a vehicle, or the leaving of a vehicle, which is reasonably necessary—

P3para.Text: for the purposes of, or in connection with, the exercise of the powers conferred by this Act with respect to works, or
for the purposes of the nominated undertaker’s undertaking under this Act.

P2para.Text: Section 10 of that Act (culverting of ditches) does not apply to anything done in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act with respect to works.

P1group.Title: Greater London Council (General Powers) Act 1986 (c. iv)

P1para.Text: The following provisions of the Greater London Council (General Powers) Act 1986 do not apply to anything done in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act with respect to works—

P3para.Text: section 5(1) (consent of borough council required for demolition of works under a street),
section 6(1) (consent of borough council required for works preventing access to premises under a street), and
section 7(1) (consent of borough council required for infilling in premises under a street).

TitleBlock.Title: Application of other railway legislation etc

P1para.Text: The Highway (Railway Crossings) Act 1839 does not apply to a railway authorised by this Act.

P2para.Text: In its application to Phase One of High Speed 2, or a train all or part of whose journey is on Phase One of High Speed 2, section 16 of the Railway Regulation Act 1840 (obstruction of officers of railway company or trespass upon railway) has effect as if—

P3para.Text: the maximum fine which may be imposed on summary conviction of the offence for which it provides were level 3 on the standard scale (instead of level 1), and

the court had, as an alternative to imposing a fine, the power to award imprisonment for a period not exceeding 51 weeks (in the case of an offence committed in England and Wales) or 12 months (in the case of an offence committed in Scotland).

P2para.Text: In relation to an offence committed in England and Wales before the commencement of section 281(5) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, the reference in sub-paragraph (1)(b) to 51 weeks is to be read as a reference to one month.

P1para.Text: Section 9 of the Railway Regulation Act 1842 does not apply to a railway authorised by this Act.

P2para.Text: The following provisions only of the Railways Clauses Consolidation Act 1845 are incorporated with this Act, in so far as they are applicable for the purposes of this Act and not inconsistent with its provisions—
In their application by virtue of sub-paragraph (1)—

P3para.Text: section 2 has effect with the substitution for “so incorporated as aforesaid” of “incorporated”;
section 6 has effect with the omission of “and to take lands for that purpose”, “taken or” and “for the value of the lands so taken or used, and”;

sections 18 and 21 do not apply in any case where the relations between the nominated undertaker and any other person are regulated by sections 84 and 85 of the New Roads and Street Works Act 1991 or Part 2 of Schedule 31 to this Act (protective provisions relating to utility undertakers);
section 46 has effect with the omission of the words from “of the height” to “in that behalf provided”;
section 68 has effect with the omission of the words from “Such and” to “formation thereof” and from “together with all necessary gates” to “all necessary stiles”.

P2para.Text: Sections 4 and 12 of the Railways Clauses Act 1863 (and section 3 of that Act so far as relating to those sections) are incorporated with this Act, in so far as applicable for the purposes of this Act and not inconsistent with its provisions.
In its application by virtue of sub-paragraph (1), section 4 has effect with the omission of—

P3para.Text: the words “and subject to the limitations contained in sections eleven, twelve, and fifteen of those Acts respectively,”, and
the words from “Provided that nothing” to the end.

P1para.Text: In its application to Phase One of High Speed 2, or a train all or part of whose journey is on Phase One of High Speed 2, section 5 of the Regulation of Railways Act 1889 has effect as follows—

P3para.Text: section 5(1) (failure to produce ticket, pay fare or give name and address) has effect as if the maximum fine which may be imposed on summary conviction of the offence for which it provides were level 2 on the standard scale (instead of level 1);
section 5(2) (power to arrest passenger who fails to produce ticket and refuses to give name and address) has effect as if after “refuses” there were inserted “or fails”;

section 5(3) (travel with intent to avoid payment of fare) has effect as if the maximum fine which may be imposed on summary conviction of the offence for which it provides were level 3 on the standard scale (instead of level 2).

P1para.Text: For the purposes of the Railway Companies (Accounts and Returns) Act 1911, a person is not a railway company by virtue of working a railway authorised by this Act.

P2para.Text: Section 55 of the British Transport Commission Act 1949 (penalty for trespass on railways etc) also applies in relation to any railway, siding, tunnel, railway embankment, cutting or similar work constructed in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act.
Section 56 of that Act (penalty for stone throwing etc on railways) also applies in relation to any railway or siding constructed in exercise of the powers conferred by this Act.
Clause 12 of the 1987 North Pole Depot undertaking (restriction on the operation of diesel locomotives on the site) does not apply in relation to—

P3para.Text: the western part of the site, or
the use of any railway or siding on any other part of the site for the purposes of access to, or stabling in connection with, a depot on the western part of the site.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of this paragraph—

Para.Text: “the 1987 North Pole Depot undertaking” means the undertaking of the British Railways Board to the London Borough of Ealing and the London Borough of Hammersmith and Fulham in relation to a proposed North Pole Depot, dated 30 March 1987;
“the site” has the meaning given by clause 1 of the undertaking;
“the western part of the site” means any part of the site which is situated on land west of Scrubs Lane.

P1group.Title: Directions as to results to be achieved

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where a difference is referred under section 41(3) to arbitration.
The parties must notify the Secretary of State of the referral without delay after the commencement of the arbitral proceedings.
The Secretary of State may, on request or otherwise, direct the arbitrator as to results that are to be achieved by the agreement for which terms are to be determined by the arbitration.

A direction under this paragraph may be made even though the making of the direction affects the outcome of proceedings to which the Secretary of State, or a body in which the Secretary of State has an interest, is a party.
A request for a direction under this paragraph may be made by the arbitrator (as well as by a party).

For the purpose of determining whether or not the arbitrator has to comply with a direction under this paragraph, the rule is that the arbitrator must comply with the direction in determining terms of the agreement if the direction—

P3para.Text: is relevant to the determination of those terms, and
is given to the arbitrator before the award determining those terms is made.

P2para.Text: For the purpose of determining what the arbitrator has to do to comply with a direction under this paragraph, the rule is that the arbitrator must carry out the function of determining terms of the agreement so as to secure, so far as is reasonably practicable, that the results concerned are achieved by the agreement.

P1group.Title: Directions as to consolidation and grouping of proceedings

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may, on request or otherwise, direct—

P3para.Text: that a group of proceedings is to be consolidated, or
that concurrent hearings are to be held in a group of proceedings.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (1) “group of proceedings” means a group consisting of—

P3para.Text: section 41(3) proceedings, and
any one or more of the following—

P4para.Text: other section 41(3) proceedings,
arbitral proceedings related to the proceedings mentioned in paragraph (a), and
arbitral proceedings related to section 41(3) proceedings that are to be consolidated with the proceedings mentioned in paragraph (a).

P2para.Text: A request for a direction under this paragraph may be made by the arbitrator or any of the arbitrators (as well as by a party).
A direction under this paragraph must specify the terms on which the proceedings are to be consolidated or on which concurrent hearings are to be held.

Where a direction under this paragraph provides for the consolidation of proceedings that do not all have the same arbitrator, the terms that may be specified in the direction include (in particular)—

P3para.Text: terms specifying the person who is to be the arbitrator in the consolidated proceedings;
terms under which that person is to be determined.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of this section—

P3para.Text: “section 41(3) proceedings” means proceedings on arbitration of a difference referred under section 41(3), and
arbitral proceedings are “related” to section 41(3) proceedings if—

P4para.Text: the arbitral proceedings are not section 41(3) proceedings,
at least one of the parties to the arbitral proceedings is also a party to the section 41(3) proceedings, and
the Secretary of State considers that the subject-matter of the arbitral proceedings is connected with the subject-matter of the section 41(3) proceedings.

P2para.Text: The property, rights and liabilities that may be the subject of a transfer scheme include in particular—

P3para.Text: rights and liabilities relating to contracts of employment;
property, rights and liabilities that would not otherwise be capable of being transferred or assigned by the transferor;
property acquired after the making of the scheme and rights and liabilities arising after the making of the scheme;
rights and liabilities under an enactment.

P2para.Text: A transfer scheme may—

P3para.Text: create rights or interests in relation to property for whose transfer the scheme provides or property retained by the transferor;
create rights and liabilities as between the transferor and a transferee or as between different transferees.

P2para.Text: A transfer scheme may contain provision about enforcement, by or against any one or more of the transferor and the transferee or transferees, of a right or liability for whose transfer or creation the scheme provides.
A transfer scheme may define the property, rights and liabilities to be transferred or property to be retained by the transferor—

P3para.Text: by specifying it or them;
by describing it or them.

P2para.Text: A description of property, rights or liabilities may be framed in particular—

P3para.Text: by reference to the transferor’s undertaking;
by reference to a specified part of that undertaking.

P1para.Text: The power under section 44 to make a scheme for the transfer of any property from one person (A) to another (B) may be exercised instead so as to make a scheme for the creation by A in favour of B of an interest in or right in relation to the property.

P1group.Title: Transfer of employees and continuity of employment

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where rights, powers, duties and liabilities relating to a person’s contract of employment are transferred in accordance with a transfer scheme.
The transfer does not break the continuity of the person’s employment, and accordingly—

P3para.Text: the person is not to be regarded for the purposes of Part 11 of the Employment Rights Act 1996 (redundancy) as having been dismissed by virtue of the transfer, and
the person’s period of employment with the transferor counts, for the purposes of that Act, as a period of employment with the transferee.

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where—

P3para.Text: a transfer scheme provides for the transfer of rights, powers, duties and liabilities relating to a person’s contract of employment, but
before the transfer takes effect, the person informs the transferor or transferee that the person objects to the transfer.

P2para.Text: Those rights, powers, duties and liabilities are not transferred to the transferee.
The person’s contract of employment is terminated immediately before the day on which the transfer would have occurred.
The person is not, for any purpose, to be regarded as having been dismissed.

Nothing in this paragraph affects the person’s right to terminate the contract of employment if, apart from the change of employer, a substantial change is made to the person’s detriment in his or her working conditions.

If a transfer scheme provides for the transfer of rights, powers, duties and liabilities relating to a person’s contract of employment, it may include provision with respect to the person’s eligibility to become a member of a pension scheme by virtue of employment with the transferee.
The transfer scheme may include provision with respect to rights of, or rights or liabilities in respect of, the person under—

P3para.Text: a pension scheme of which the person may become a member by virtue of employment with the transferee, or
a pension scheme of which the person is a member by virtue of employment immediately before the transfer.

P1para.Text: Where a person holds employment in the civil service of the State on terms which do not constitute a contract of employment—

P3para.Text: the person is to be treated for the purposes of this Schedule as employed under a contract of employment,
the terms of the employment in the civil service of the State are to be treated for those purposes as the terms of that contract, and
the reference in paragraph 4 to dismissal is to be read as a reference to termination of the employment in the civil service of the State.

P1group.Title: Provision for contraventions etc to be treated as not occurring

P2para.Text: A transfer scheme may provide for a transfer to take effect as if there were no contravention or liability, or interference with any interest or right, that there would otherwise be as a result of a provision which has effect (whether under an enactment or agreement or otherwise) in relation to—

P3para.Text: the terms on which the transferor is entitled to the property or right for whose transfer the scheme provides, or
the terms on which the transferor is subject to the liability for whose transfer the scheme provides.

P2para.Text: A transfer scheme may provide for the creation of an interest in or right in relation to property to take effect as if there were no contravention or liability, or interference with any interest or right, that there would otherwise be as a result of a provision which has effect (whether under an enactment or agreement or otherwise) in relation to—

P3para.Text: the terms on which the transferor is entitled to the property, or
the terms on which a subsidiary of the transferor is entitled or subject to anything immediately before the creation of the interest or right takes effect.

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where a transfer scheme provides for the transfer of shares in a subsidiary of the transferor.

The scheme may provide for the transfer to take effect as if there were no contravention or liability, or interference with any right or interest, that there would otherwise be as a result of a provision which has effect (whether under an enactment or agreement or otherwise) in relation to the terms on which the subsidiary is entitled or subject to anything immediately before the transfer takes effect.

P1group.Title: Power to modify interests, rights and liabilities of third parties

P2para.Text: A transfer scheme may modify interests, rights or liabilities of third parties in relation to anything to which the scheme relates.
In sub-paragraph (1), “third party”, in relation to a scheme, means a person other than the transferor or a transferee.
Where a person would (apart from this paragraph) have a qualifying entitlement in consequence of—

P3para.Text: property, rights or liabilities having been, or being likely to be, transferred under a transfer scheme,
interests, rights or liabilities having been, or being likely to be, created under a transfer scheme, or
anything else having been done, or being likely to be done, by or under a transfer scheme,

P2para.Text: that entitlement is enforceable, in consequence of the circumstances mentioned in paragraph (a), (b) or (c), only to the extent specified in the scheme.
In this paragraph, “qualifying entitlement”, in relation to a transfer scheme, means an entitlement—

P3para.Text: to terminate, modify, acquire or claim an interest or right to which the transferor, or a subsidiary of the transferor, is entitled or subject, or
to treat an interest or right to which the transferor, or a subsidiary of the transferor, is entitled or subject as modified or terminated.

P1group.Title: Obligations to enter into agreements or execute instruments

P2para.Text: A transfer scheme may contain provision for imposing, on the transferor or a transferee, obligations—

P3para.Text: to enter into agreements with persons specified in the scheme, or
to execute instruments in favour of persons specified in the scheme.

P2para.Text: Any person may be specified by virtue of sub-paragraph (1)(a) or (b) (including the transferor or a transferee).
Where a scheme contains provision for imposing an obligation of the kind mentioned in sub-paragraph (1)—

P3para.Text: the scheme must specify or describe the agreement or instrument to which the obligation relates, and
the obligation may be enforced in any authorised way by the person—

P4para.Text: with whom the agreement is to be entered into, or
in favour of whom the instrument is to be executed.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (3)(b), “enforced in any authorised way” means enforced—

P3para.Text: in civil proceedings for an injunction,
in civil proceedings for any other appropriate remedy or relief, or
in any other way authorised by the scheme.

P2para.Text: The scheme may provide that sub-paragraph (4)(a) or (b)—

P3para.Text: does not apply in relation to the obligation, or
applies in relation to the obligation subject to restrictions imposed by the scheme.

P2para.Text: A transfer scheme may include consequential, supplementary, incidental, and transitional provision.
That includes, in particular, provision—

P3para.Text: saving the effect of things done by or in relation to the transferor,
for a transferee to be treated as the same person in law as the transferor,
for things done by or in relation to the transferor to be treated as done by or in relation to a transferee,
for things (including legal proceedings) being done by or in relation to the transferor to be continued by or in relation to a transferee, and
for references in a document (other than in an enactment) to the transferor, or to an employee or office-holder of the transferor, to have effect with modifications specified in the scheme.

P2para.Text: At the time appointed for the purpose by a transfer scheme, property, rights and liabilities for whose transfer the scheme provides are transferred in accordance with the scheme.
A scheme may appoint different times for the transfer of different things.

References in this paragraph to the transfer of property, rights and liabilities include references to the creation of interests, rights or liabilities under paragraph 1 or 2 (and “transferred”, in relation to property, rights or liabilities, is to be read accordingly).
Where the transferor, and the transferee or transferees, under a transfer scheme so agree, the scheme is to be treated for all purposes as having been made with such modifications as may be agreed.
Sub-paragraph (1) does not apply in the case of an agreement relating to rights and liabilities under a contract of employment unless the employee is a party to the agreement.

Sub-paragraph (1) does not apply in the case of an agreement that adversely affects the property or rights of a person other than the transferor or a transferee unless that person is a party to the agreement.
An agreement under sub-paragraph (1) may make—

P3para.Text: any provision that could have been contained in the scheme, and
consequential, supplementary, incidental or transitional provision in connection with giving effect to any such provision.

P2para.Text: Provision under sub-paragraph (4) may be made so as to have effect from when the scheme was made (or any later time).

P1group.Title: Provision of information to person making scheme

P2para.Text: Where the Secretary of State proposes to make a transfer scheme, the Secretary of State may direct—

P3para.Text: a proposed transferor,
a proposed transferee, or
High Speed Two (HS2) Limited,

P2para.Text: to provide the Secretary of State with such information as the Secretary of State considers necessary to enable the scheme to be made.
A direction under sub-paragraph (1) must specify the period (of not less than 28 days beginning with the day when the direction is given) within which the information is to be provided.
If a person fails to comply with the direction, the Secretary of State may give the person a notice requiring the person—

P3para.Text: to produce to the Secretary of State, at a time and place specified in the notice, any documents which are specified or described in the notice and are in the person’s custody or control, or
to provide to the Secretary of State, at a time and place and in the form and manner specified in the notice, such information as may be specified or described in the notice.

P2para.Text: No person may be required under sub-paragraph (3)—

P3para.Text: to produce a document which the person could not be compelled to produce in civil proceedings in the High Court, or
to provide information which the person could not be compelled to give in evidence in such proceedings.

P2para.Text: If a person fails to comply with a notice under sub-paragraph (3), the High Court may, on the application of the Secretary of State, make such order as the court thinks fit for requiring the failure to be made good.
Any order under sub-paragraph (5) may include provision requiring all the costs and expenses of and incidental to the application to be borne by one or more of—

P3para.Text: the person in default, and
any officers of a body corporate or other association who are responsible for its default.

P2para.Text: In this paragraph, a reference to producing a document includes a reference to producing a legible and intelligible copy of information recorded otherwise than in legible form.

P1para.Text: The Secretary of State may by agreement fetter the exercise of his or her discretion relating to his or her powers under this Schedule.

P1group.Title: Power to make provision about tax consequences of schemes

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by regulations make provision for varying the way in which a relevant tax has effect from time to time in relation to—

Text.Emphasis: any property, rights or liabilities transferred in accordance with a transfer scheme, or
anything done for the purposes of, or in relation to, or in consequence of, the transfer of any property, rights or liabilities in accordance with a transfer scheme.

P2para.Text: The provision that may be made under sub-paragraph (1)(a) includes, in particular, provision for—

Text.Emphasis: a tax provision not to apply, or to apply with modifications, in relation to any property, rights or liabilities transferred;
any property, rights or liabilities transferred to be treated in a specified way for the purposes of a tax provision;

the Secretary of State to be required or permitted, with the consent of the Treasury, to determine, or to specify the method for determining, anything which needs to be determined for the purposes of any tax provision so far as relating to any property, rights or liabilities transferred.

P2para.Text: The provision that may be made under sub-paragraph (1)(b) includes, in particular, provision for—

Text.Emphasis: a tax provision not to apply, or to apply with modifications, in relation to anything done for the purposes of, or in relation to, or in consequence of, the transfer;
anything done for the purposes of, or in relation to, or in consequence of, the transfer to have or not to have a specified consequence or to be treated in a specified way;
